Python 2.7: 'module' object has no attribute 'lru_cache'
items.body:
Hi,

Version 2.5.0 crashes on Python 2.7 even though it's described as py2-compatible.

```
  File "/home/emes/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django_jinja/backend.py", line 114, in <module>
    class Jinja2(BaseEngine):
  File "/home/emes/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django_jinja/backend.py", line 118, in Jinja2
    @functools.lru_cache()
AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'lru_cache'
```

Apparently, `functools.lru_cache` doesn't exist in py2.

items.title: Can we extend Django templates?
items.body:
I am using [django-adminlte2](https://github.com/adamcharnock/django-adminlte2) for the overall site structure as well as the theme for my admin pages.

Many such theme extensions exist and are a staple amongst Django users.

Hence my question:
**Is there any way we can within a jinja-template inherit from a Django-template?**

I have not been able to do it so far, as I get the known error of:
> Encountered unknown tag 'load'.

Django attempts to use jinja to render the parent template as well, which fails as Jinja obviously does not understand `{% load static %}`.

Rewriting all parent templates is not a solution due to the amount of work such endeavour would require.

Is there maybe any configuration we can change or even a possible monkey patch to mix Django and Jinja to play nicely together? If not, I feel the docs need to make it clear that we can not have heterogenous inheritance, hence severely limiting the use of any Django theme extensions.

It would be great if you could shine some light on this issue. Thanks.

items.title: 2.3.1 breaks public `Template` interface
items.body:
This commit https://github.com/niwinz/django-jinja/commit/406333ce589e91debcd3a1db3f79de9cabf76524 has made it so that the `Template` object no longer has a `template` attribute.  This is a compatibility breaking change for libraries that assume it to be present - the public interface for `Template` objects is now changed.

I'm not really sure what a solution could be for this.  From what I understand, the code exhibiting the problem is in django's `IncludeNode`.  So, this is covering the case where a django template includes a jinja template?

items.title: django-jinja does not accept template loaders so can not work with a non-typical folder structure like cookiecutter-django
items.body:
cookiecutter-django uses a folder structure with the 'templates' folder outside of the individual app folders and uses the following lines in the settings file for a file system template loader to find the templates in a the non-typical location. django-jinja does not accept the 'loaders' OPTION and there is now way to point it to a folder outside of the individual app folders for templates.

```

TEMPLATES = [
    {
        # See: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/ref/settings/#std:setting-TEMPLATES-BACKEND
        'BACKEND': 'django.template.backends.django.DjangoTemplates',
        # See: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/ref/settings/#template-dirs
        'DIRS': [
            str(APPS_DIR.path('templates')),
        ],
        'OPTIONS': {
            # See: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/ref/settings/#template-debug
            'debug': DEBUG,
            # See: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/ref/settings/#template-loaders
            # https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/ref/templates/api/#loader-types
            'loaders': [
                'django.template.loaders.filesystem.Loader',
                'django.template.loaders.app_directories.Loader',
            ],
            # See: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/ref/settings/#template-context-processors
            'context_processors': [
                'django.template.context_processors.debug',
                'django.template.context_processors.request',
                'django.contrib.auth.context_processors.auth',
                'django.template.context_processors.i18n',
                'django.template.context_processors.media',
                'django.template.context_processors.static',
                'django.template.context_processors.tz',
                'django.contrib.messages.context_processors.messages',
                # Your stuff: custom template context processors go here
            ],
        },
    },
]
```

items.title: Extension decorator should return the class
items.body:
Using the `@library.extension` decorator (in master, it doesn't work in 1.4.1 as per #153) results in the class being set to `None` in the module where it is defined, which isn't a massive deal since it does get registered – unless you happen to reference the class in the file (or anywhere else) e.g. in a `super` call.

I expect the decorator needs to just return the class unmodified since all it's doing is appending it to the array of extensions.

items.body:
If I do not use `match_extension`, but have `"match_regex": r'.*\.(j2|jinja)$',` then it doesn't really works. So either behavior or docs should be updated.

items.title: Multiple template backend causes django-jinja loaders to be overridden
makemessages does not grab translation string in template
items.body:
It's a rather exotic thing and I'm not sure if that's a Django bug or a django-jinja issue. Having this rather unusual structure in a template, makemessages isn't able to grab the second translation string:

```
{{ bool and _("Translate me 1") or _("Translate me 1") }}
```

`bool` can be any expression returning `True` or `False`.

It works properly though by using an extra if statement:

```
{% if bool %}{{ _("Translate me 1") }}{% else %}{{ _("Translate me 2") }}{% endif %}
```

items.title: Add support for django’s makemessages command with newstyle_gettext
items.body:
With this requirements.txt,

```
Django==1.8.2
Jinja2==2.7.3
django-jinja==1.4.1
```

`manage.py makemessages` can't find translation strings with `newstyle_gettext` format, such as
`{{ _('Hello %(name)s', name=user.name) }}`.

In contrast, `manage.py makemessages` is able to find these translation strings
`{{ _('Hello %(name)s')|format(name=user.name) }}`,
and
`{% trans name=user.name %}Hello {{ name }}{% endtrans %}`.

items.body:
The following is with django-jinja 1.4.3 and django1.8.2. Compare the two runs between a template loading the default Django template language and the other using Jinja2 via django-jinja: ``` (jinja2test) [bafflermeal@kdev05:/apps/sites/jinja2test/top]15> cat cases/templates/cases/label_tag_example.html {% for field in NEW_CASE_FORM %}
{{ field.errors }} {{ field.label_tag }} {{ field }}
{% endfor %} (jinja2test) [bafflermeal@kdev05:/apps/sites/jinja2test/top]16> cat cases/templates/cases/label_tag_example.jinja {% for field in NEW_CASE_FORM %}
{{ field.errors }} {{ field.label_tag }} {{ field }}
{% endfor %} (jinja2test) [bafflermeal@kdev05:/apps/sites/jinja2test/top]17> >>> from cases.models import Case >>> from cases.forms import CaseForm >>> from django.http import HttpResponse, HttpResponseRedirect >>> from django.template import loader, RequestContext, Template >>> context = { 'NEW_CASE_FORM': CaseForm() } >>> template = loader.get_template('cases/label_tag_example.html') >>> template.render(context=context) '\n
\n \n
\n\n
\n \n
\n\n' >>> template = loader.get_template('cases/label_tag_example.jinja',using='django_jinja') >>> template.render(context=context) '\n
\n <bound method BoundField.label_tag of <django.forms.forms.BoundField object at 0x2b557e9e8390>> \n
\n\n
\n <bound method BoundField.label_tag of <django.forms.forms.BoundField object at 0x2b557e9e8400>> \n
\n' ``` Note that the template render using the same context with `using='django_jinja'` yields messages such as: `bound method BoundField.label_tag of ` when referencing some items in a `ModelForm` after `.is_valid()` has been run. The same code doesn't appear to cause any issues with the Django template language loader. This error comes from trying to print `{{ field.label_tag }}` in the example.

items.title: safe filter with undefined variable, change since 1.0.3
items.body: Lets say I have, in view: ``` if whatever: self.context['link'] = 'here' % link ``` then in the template ``` view the thing {{ link|safe }}. ``` If `whatever` is true and link is set all is well and the above becomes a link ``` view the thing here. ``` but if `whatever` is false and link is not set, eg. is undefined it gives ``` view the thing {{ link }}. ``` Eg. the tag doesn't get interpreted to remove the `|safe`. This is different from the behavior without the safe filter and has occurred between v1.0.3 and v1.3.3. I don't know where as we upgraded straight from 1.0.3 to 1.3.3. IMHO this is seems like the wrong behavior (I think from memory it's different to standard django?) but if it's intention that's fine. Temporary fix is ``` view the thing {{ link or ''|safe }}. ```

items.title: match_extension not reliably catching all Jinja2 templates
Severe parsing errors?
items.body:
I'm observing some strange behaviors when using Django 1.8 RC1. They look very much like parsing errors:

1) Outputting a variable that doesn't actually exist in the template's context. E.g. just writing {{ x }}, while "x" does not exist, should output nothing - or None or it should result in an error. However, it simply outputs the whole fragment "{{ x }}" as string. Same for {{ abc }} results in an output of "{{ abc }}", when there's no variable names "abc".

2) Probably related: {{ request.GET.var|e }} should output the escaped value of the request param "var". Yet, when "var" does not exist, the output should be empty or None - or error. However, this _prints_ actually the error message that such a key does not exist in the query dict. That's very inconvenient and probably a but.

3) {{ request.GET.var or request.POST.var }} should either output the GET or POST param "var", or if neither exists, the output should be empty. However, if neither exists, we get to see the error message mentioned above.

There are workarounds, but it would be really great if that could be fixed. It was working fine with Django 1.7 and the previous version of django_jinja. Using workarounds makes conversions from Django's template engine to django_jinja very hard.

Thanks again for looking into this!

1) Does the settings constant JINJA2_AUTOESCAPE still have any effect in Django 1.8? If not, how do you turn off autoescaping?

2) Elementary template functions are not working, and I have no idea why. E.g. translation strings {{ _(...) }} or the {{ super() }} block insertion.

'loaders': [('django.template.loaders.cached.Loader', ['django_jinja.loaders.AppLoader', 'django_jinja.loaders.FileSystemLoader'])],

Any help appreciated :-)) Thanks for this great app!

items.title: Missing possibility to use custom Undefined subclass
items.body:
make_env function unconditionally ignores and overwrites the 'undefined' attribute in JINJA2_ENVIRONMENT_OPTIONS. So its impossible to use 'Undefined' subclasses other than 'Undefined' itself or 'DebugUndefined'

``` python
 if settings.DEBUG:
        initial_params["undefined"] = jinja2.DebugUndefined
    else:
        initial_params["undefined"] = jinja2.Undefined
```

So I suppose there should be some test if 'undefined' is already in initial_params.

items.title: Django 1.9 deprecation warning
items.body:
After upgrading from Django 1.7 to Django 1.8, and changing my settings file for the 1.8 django-jinja integration, I get the following warning. I'm running on Python 3.4.

```
(medpilot-2)leonard@ubuntu ~> python manage.py shell
.../lib/python3.4/importlib/_bootstrap.py:321: RemovedInDjango19Warning: django.utils.importlib will be removed in Django 1.9.
  return f(*args, **kwds)
```

The warning can be attributed to the following line:
https://github.com/niwibe/django-jinja/blob/3d6ecfef493d3fdaed3cab8a2ba198899d253622/django_jinja/base.py#L12

Since django-jinja officially supports >= python 2.7, it should be safe to change it into the following:

``` python
from importlib import import_module
```

... as django utils uses it for python versions < 2.7. https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.7/releases/1.7/#django-utils-dictconfig-django-utils-importlib

Thoughts?

items.title: Including Jinja templates from a Django template is broken in Django 1.8
items.body:
I think this is due to this issue https://code.djangoproject.com/ticket/24425 and specifically this line in 1.8 https://github.com/django/django/blob/8e129b42ad9c9adca599228ae2ad68271fa46d44/django/template/loader_tags.py#L151

This seems to cause the `include` tag to always use the same template engine it started in which prevents django-jinja from doing it's job. Does this need fixing upstream or should django-jinja be implementing some kind of extra smart template engine that can delegate to the DTL backend when necessary?

items.title: django 1.8 support
items.body:
Current django-jinja is not compatible with django-1.8.

It [refers](https://github.com/niwibe/django-jinja/blob/master/django_jinja/base.py#L297) `app_directories.app_template_dirs`, which has been [removed](https://github.com/django/django/commit/d58597a7b8b47add828c9418cdf48299e3b8f5bb#diff-6650649b07e8476415718effff1d57afL36) from `app_directories` module. 

Something like this should be used:

```
from django.template.utils import get_app_template_dirs
get_app_template_dirs('templates')
```

items.title: Recommend using the global namespace instead of "context processors"
items.body:
The documentation advertises support for "context processors" as an advantage over Django's native Jinja2 backend.

I believe that's an anti-feature. Context processors are a poor API. Jinja2's [global namespace](http://jinja.pocoo.org/docs/dev/api/#the-global-namespace) is a superior replacement.

Most built-in context processors don't depend on the request in practice and many return a constant. There's no reason to make a function call and pass the request object in that case.

I understand that the goal of django-jinja is to make jinja2 look like the Django Template Language. That requires recreating some mistakes that Django made and Jinja fixed. Nonetheless I would suggest pointing to the better solution in the documentation, in that case, the global namespace.

items.title: Why Django 1.8 puts Jinja templates in a different directory
items.body:
Currently the documentation says:

> jinja2 are also templates, I don’t understand why put them in different directory

The answer is [here](https://github.com/django/deps/blob/master/accepted/0182-multiple-template-engines.rst#engine-selection). django-jinja implements option 3, while Django chose option 4.

You're welcome to disagree, but at least you should understand before disagreeing :-)

items.title: Default behavior of the `undefined` option.
items.body:
First, thanks for all the good work to make django-jinja compatible with the future version 1.8 of Django!

I want to draw your attention on something  that isn't that important, but I was very surprised by a change in the behavior between an older version 1.0.x and a the new versions 1.1.x. This change comes from [these few lines](https://github.com/niwibe/django-jinja/blob/51970a68557e16af4c2b1dd3b616e88ac6f43846/django_jinja/backend.py#L52): 

``` python
if settings.DEBUG:
    options.setdefault("undefined", jinja2.DebugUndefined)
else:
    options.setdefault("undefined", jinja2.Undefined)
```

The good news is: it works as before in production, with `DEBUG = False`. So no big deal here in the end. However, as it's new to versions 1.1.x, I would like two little things (if it's possible or worth the time):
- A small line or two about the `undefined` option in the documentation,
- And maybe use `settings.TEMPLATE_DEBUG` instead of `settings.DEBUG`?

I was very surprised when I tried locally and saw all these `{{ some_var }}` in my rendered HTML, and I was confused for a minute that `settings.TEMPLATE_DEBUG = False` didn't work as expected.

I could provide a PR, but maybe you want to keep `settings.DEBUG`? And maybe there are other options I don't know about that deserve a modification/a line in the doc/etc.

items.title: Django 1.8 support

Since django 1.8.x, django comes with native multiple template engine support.

items.title: Bug with pipeline PIPELINE_CSS, extra_context > media
items.body:
If I specify:

```
PIPELINE_CSS = {
    'bootstrap': {
        'source_filenames': ('libs/css/bootstrap.css',),
        'output_filename': 'css/bootstrap.css',
        'extra_context': {'media': 'all'},
    },
}
```

Then:

```
{{ compressed_css('bootstrap') }} --> <link href="/static/libs/css/bootstrap.css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" media="all" />
```

(which is fine).

But if I specify:

```
PIPELINE_CSS = {
    'bootstrap': {
        'source_filenames': ('libs/css/bootstrap.css',),
        'output_filename': 'css/bootstrap.css',
    },
}
```

Then:

```
{{ compressed_css('bootstrap') }} --> <link href="/static/libs/css/bootstrap.css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" media="<function media at 0x7f2d7dfac140>" />
```

[According to pipeline docs](http://django-pipeline.readthedocs.org/en/latest/configuration.html#extra-context) the default for media should be `"all"`.

Looks like the function simply isn't being evaluated?
